Award.AwardTitle: Planning Project to Establish a Cohesive Community College STEM Institutional Transformation Academy - STEM-UP Academy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) provides support for the design, implementation, and assessment of strategies that can lead to comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Hinds Community College - Utica seeks to establish the foundation for a "Cohesive Community College STEM Institutional Transformation Academy". The goals of the project are: to establish summer bridge programs, to strengthen the 2-year STEM curriculum at the college, and to facilitate entrance of students into 4-year STEM programs.

Activities that are part of this project are: meetings with the advisory boards and partnering school districts and universities for planning purposes; faculty development and training in redesigning of science, mathematics, and computer science courses; a two- week summer pre-college bridge program for rising 11th graders; a five-week summer pre-college component for entering STEM freshman; and collaborations with partnering 4-year institutions, such as Jackson State University and Alcorn University. The project will be guided by an on-going evaluation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hinds Community College-Utica Campus (HCCUC) received a National Science Foundation (NSF) Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Planning Grant to establish the foundation for a "Cohesive Community College STEM Institutional Transformation Academy". The goals of the one-year planning grant were to establish Summer Bridge programs, to strengthen the 2-year science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) curriculum at the college, and to facilitate entrance of students into 4-year STEM programs. Additionally, HCCUC was awarded supplemental funding to create an Institute for STEM Academic Research. The Institute’s overall goal was to strengthen the research capacity of faculty at HCCUC, in order create a campus environment that is conducive to promoting research and scholarly activities. The one-year grant, and subsequent no-cost extension which included the supplemental funding, covered the transitional period from the first 2010-2015 HBCU-UP Implementation Grant and subsequent grants to expand STEM offerings and build institutional capacity.

During the summer of 2016, 21 high school students, four high school STEM teachers, and five HCCUC STEM faculty were selected to participate in a Summer STEM Academic Integrated Learning Camp. Part of the camp included visiting NASA Stennis Space Center in Hancock County, Mississippi. During the visit, they were able to listen to presentations about careers with NASA; had a windshield tour of the NASA’s Propulsion Test Complex; and toured the Aerojet Rocketdyne’s Engine Assembly Facility.

Also during the summer of 2016, 28 prospective HCCUC students were selected to participate in the Utica Campus Community College (UC³) College Success Camp (CSC). All 28 students completed the camp successfully and enrolled at HCCUC as STEM majors and were supported through grant funding with tuition, room and board, supplies and science trips.

Faculty was supported through grant funding as well. Two STEM Faculty attended the STEMtech Conference in Phoenix, Arizona, which was hosted by The League of Innovation in the Community College. Five STEM faculty participated in training that focused on the Flipped STEM Classroom. During the Flipped STEM Classroom professional development training, the following techniques were shared on how 1) to monitor students’ progress; 2) use existing technology to ease faculty and students into a flipped mindset; and 3) assess students' understanding of pre-class assignments to make the best use of class time.  To date approximately three of five STEM faculty are embracing this new approach. Lastly, all seven STEM faculty as well as one English faculty were involved in training and carrying out Process Education activities. English was added to the new/reconstituted agenda to build students’ communication—technical and creative writing and speaking—skills.

Connections were made with another department at HCCUC and local 4-year institutions to establish collaborations to ensure a seamless transition for community college STEM majors. The Title III Department at HCCUC provided five promethean boards that were placed in each STEM classroom. There was one non-STEM/English faculty who was highly motivated to engage in using technology who served as a lead faculty. Four collaborations activities were established with four 4-year institutions that provided a variety of educational and professional opportunities for students and faculty at HCCUC.

Using the supplemental funding, in the fall of 2016, 19 participants were selected to participate in the Institute for STEM Academic Research. The 19 participants included eight faculty with four from natural science, three from social science and one from humanities; eight staff members in which one was from the Natural Science Department, two were from the library, one was from career and technical education, one from health science, and three from student services; and three administrators that included the campus Vice President, the Dean of Career and Technical Education, and the Title III Executive Director. Of the 19 participants selected, 15 administrators, faculty and staff chose to participate in the Article Writing Retreat. Fifteen literature reviews were completed. Topics included: Engaging STEM Students in Composition; Fostering a Community College Partnership between Librarians and STEM Faculty; Strategies to Increase Retention of STEM Students; and Recruiting and Retaining Minority STEM Majors. All 15 participants have completed and submitted articles and/or literature reviews to be published in journals. Of the 19 selected participants, 11 administrators, faculty and staff chose to participate in the STEM Proposal Writing Retreat. Two STEM grant proposals are in progress to be submitted to NSF’s Division of Undergraduate Education; one to Advanced Technological Education and one to the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education.

In conclusion, HCC-Utica used this transitional planning grant and supplemental funding to strategically lay foundation for next steps for developing bridges for high school students, engaging students in conferences and industry visits, providing research exposures for students and signaling the importance of research and scholarly writing activities to its faculty, fostering transformational instruction and building collaborations with four year institutions. Additionally, the foundation to facilitate the entrance of students into 4-year STEM programs was developed.
